perturbation.explanation: The original section 6.2 provides the Sponsor with broad discretion to terminate the agreement. The modified section introduces limitations to this discretion by requiring good faith negotiations, allowing the Issuer opportunities to rectify breaches, and imposing conditions on the Sponsor's right to terminate. This creates a contradiction because the original text implies the Sponsor can terminate at its sole discretion, while the modified text introduces constraints on that discretion. This could lead to disputes about the Sponsor's ability to terminate the agreement.

The original section states the issuer bears all costs and expenses. The modified version adds an exception where the Sponsor is responsible for their own legal fees in specific circumstances (disputes arising from legal actions taken by the Issuer or the Sponsor declining to sign the certificate after requested modification to the contract). This creates a contradiction because the original implies the issuer always pays, while the modified text introduces an exception. This could lead to disagreements about who is responsible for certain legal costs.

perturbation.original_text: This Agreement will be governed by the law of British Columbia and the parties attorn to the non-exclusive jurisdiction of the courts of British Columbia for the resolution of all disputes arising in connection with this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement will be governed by the law of British Columbia. However, any disputes regarding intellectual property rights or breaches of confidentiality shall be subject to arbitration in Toronto, Ontario, under the laws of Ontario, and the parties submit to the exclusive jurisdiction of the arbitration panel in Toronto for such disputes. All other disputes will be governed by the law of British Columbia and the parties attorn to the non-exclusive jurisdiction of the courts of British Columbia for the resolution of all disputes arising in connection with this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: The original text states that all disputes are subject to the non-exclusive jurisdiction of British Columbia courts. The modified text introduces an exception, stating that disputes related to intellectual property or confidentiality are subject to arbitration in Toronto and to the exclusive jurisdiction of the arbitration panel. This creates a direct contradiction, as it is now unclear where a dispute should be resolved depending on its nature.
